markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1911 (JJM) THE GENERAL TYPE OF CAST - IRON MONUMENT OF 1872-76 ARE HOLLOW IRON CASTINGS IN THE FORM OF A TRUNCATED PYRAMID 8 FEET HIGH, 8 INCHES SQUARE AT THE BOTTOM, 4 INCHES SQUARE AT THE TOP, WITH A SOLID PYRAMIDAL CAP,  AND A HEAVY FLANGE AT THE BOTTOM.  UPON OPPOSITE FACES, THE SOUTH AND THE NORTH, ARE CAST, IN RAISED LETTERS 2 INCHES HIGH, THE INSCRIPTIONS---CONVENTION OF LONDON---AND ---OCTOBER 20, 1818---.  THESE MONUMENTS HAD BEEN SET ALONG THE SOUTHERN BOUNDARY OF MANITOBA BY THE COMMISSION OF 1872-76.  EIGHTY FIVE OF THESE, CORRESPONDING TO THE PRESENT NUMBERING 748 TO 832, WERE SET WEST OF RED RIVER.  ABOUT 60 WERE FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION IN 1911.  THEY WERE FILLED WITH CONCRETE AND RESET IN CONCRETE BASES WITH THE TOP OF THE OBELISK 5 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND.  THE BROKEN ONES AND ALSO THOSE THAT HAD ORIGINALLY BEEN SET EAST OF RED RIVER WERE DESTROYED AND REPLACED BY NEW CAST - IRON MONUMENTS OF THE STYLE MADE IN 1908-13.  THE MONUMENTS CAST IN 1908-13, BEARS THE FOLLOWING INSCRIPTIONS, CAST IN RAISED LETTERS--ON THE NORTH FACE---CANADA---, ON THE SOUTH FACE ---UNITED STATES---, ON THE EAST FACE---CONVENTION OF 1818---, ON THE WEST FACE---TREATY OF 1908---.  THE INSCRIPTIONS READ VERTICALLY FROM BOTTOM TO TOP.  THE NUMBER OF THE MONUMENT IS OUTLINED WITH DRILL HOLES TO THE FACE OF THE SHAFT.  THE MONUMENTS SET IN THE---MERIDIAN LINE---WERE TURNED SO THAT---UNITED STATES---APPEARS ON THE EAST SIDE AND---CANADA---ON THE WEST SIDE.  THESE MONUMENTS WERE FILLED WITH CONCRETE AND SET IN CONCRETE BASES WITH THE TOP OF THE SHAFT 5 FEET ABOVE THE GROUND.  THEY WERE USED IN 1908-13 TO MARK THE LINE FROM MONUMENT 303 EASTWARD TO THE NORTHWESTERNMOST POINT OF LAKE OF THE WOODS EXCEPT WHERE THE CAST - IRON MONUMENTS OF 1872-76 WERE RESET AS HERETOFORE DESCRIBED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1911)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1911 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1946)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1946 (RKL) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1988)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1988 THE MONUMENT IS LOCATED ABOUT 6.43 KM (4.00 MI) NORTHWEST OF PEMBINA AND ABOUT 6.03 KM (3.75 MI) WEST OF THE PEMBINA, NORTH DAKOTA - EMERSON, MANITOBA BORDER CROSSING. TO REACH THE MONUMENT FROM CANADIAN COSTOMS AT EMERSON, MANITOBA, GO NORTH TOWARDS WINNIPEG ON PROVINCIAL HIGHWAY 75 FOR 1.93 KM (1.20 MI) TO THE JUNCTION OF PROVINCIAL ROAD 243 ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO WEST ON PROVINCIAL ROAD 243, GRAVEL, FOR 5.79 KM (3.60 MI) TO A GRAVEL CROSSROAD.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON A GRAVEL ROAD FOR 0.97 KM (0.60 MI) TO A DRIVEWAY AT THE BYRON AND JOANN HEINRICHS FARM. CONTINUE SOUTH ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.64 KM (0.40 MI) TO A DIRT T-ROAD AT THE BOUNDARY.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST ALONG THE CANADIAN SIDE OF THE BOUNDARY ON THE DIRT ROAD FOR 0.24 KM (0.15 MI) TO THE MONUMENT ON THE LEFT. THE MONUMENT IS A CAST-IRON OBELISK WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 0.86 M (2.8 FT) ABOVE THE GROUND.  INSCRIBED ON THE OBELISK IN RAISED, CAST LETTERS IS --CONVENTION OF LONDON-- ON THE NORTH SIDE AND --OCTOBER 20TH 1818-- ON THE SOUTH SIDE.  THE NUMBER --827-- IS DRILLED NEAR THE TOP OF THE EAST SIDE OF THE OBELISK. THE POINT POSITIONED IS THE APEX OF THE OBELISK. TYPE BY M.L.B.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

STATION RECOVERY (1931)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1931 (MB) RECOVERED, AND IN GOOD CONDITION.  STANDARD GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA CONCRETE POST AND BRONZE TABLET MARKS THE POSITION. THIS STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3 FEET WEST OF FENCE LINE IN CULTIVATED FIELD, ON THE SOUTHWEST QUARTER SEC. 33, T. 1, R. 23 W., PRINCIPAL MERIDIAN, ON PROPERTY BELONGING TO MR. GASTON SUNAERT, WHO LIVES ON THE PROPERTY.  REACHED FROM GOODLANDS, MANITOBA BY ROAD LEADING EAST FROM SOUTH EDGE OF THE VILLAGE.  FOLLOW THIS ROAD (WHICH BEARS RIGHT THROUGH FIELDS AFTER REACHING TOP OF HILL) TO A GATE AND NORTH-AND-SOUTH LANE ABOUT ONE-HALF MILE BEYOND FARM BUILDINGS.  TURN RIGHT IN THIS LANE AND TAKE FIRST ROAD IN LANE LEADING TO LEFT (EAST), FOLLOW THIS ROAD EAST TO FIRST FARM BUILDINGS ON LEFT.  STATION IS ABOUT 500 YARDS NORTHEAST OF FARMHOUSE, BY FENCE ON TOP OF RIDGE IN OPEN FIELD.  OLD ROAD MENTIONED IN ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS CLOSED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1970)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US AIR FORCE 1970 STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED IN GOOD CONDITION.  ROUTE DESCRIPTION WAS ADEQUATE.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1980 (MDC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7 1/2 MILES NORTH - NORTHEAST OF WARROAD, 6 1/2 MILES EAST OF WHERE THE INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY INTERSECTS STATE HIGHWAY 313, ON THE BUFFALO POINT INDIAN RESERVATION, AND ON THE EXTREME SOUTHEAST POINT OF BUFFALO POINT. PERMISSION TO CROSS THE RESERVATION AND ESTABLISH THE STATION WAS GRANTED BY MR JIM THUNDER, CHIEF OF THE RESERVATION, AND HIS BROTHER, FRANK.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 11 AND 313 AT THE NORTHWEST EDGE OF WARROAD, GO NORTH ON STATE HIGHWAY 313 FOR 6.5 MILES TO THE CANADIAN CUSTOMS.  CONTINUE FOR 0.1 MILE TO A GRAVEL SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST ON THE GRAVEL ROAD FOR 6.4 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  CONTINUE FOR 0.15 MILE TO A CROSSROAD.  CONTINUE FOR 0.35 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AT A LARGE TREE IN THE MIDDLE OF THE ROAD.  CONTINUE FOR 0.05 MILE TO A TRACK ROAD RIGHT.  BEAR RIGHT ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.85 MILE TO THE END OF THE ROAD AT THE SHORE OF BUFFALO BAY.  FROM HERE, PACK SOUTHERLY ALONG THE SHORE FOR ABOUT 3 TO 5 MINUTES TO THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED FRANK 1980.  IT IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A BOULDER THAT IS APPROXIMATELY 4 BY 7 FEET AND PROJECTS ABOUT 18 INCHES ABOVE THE SURROUNDING AREA.  THE STATION WAS ESTABLISHED IN THE SUMMER OF A VERY DRY YEAR, THEREFORE, DURING A NORMAL YEAR, THE STATION MARK COULD BE UNDER WATER.  IT IS 22 FEET EAST OF THE TREE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED FRANK NO 1 1980.  IT IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A FLAT BOULDER THAT IS 3 FEET IN DIAMETER AND PROJECTS ABOUT 1 FOOT.  IT IS AT THE EDGE OF THE TREE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED FRANK NO 2 1980.  IT IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE BOULDER THAT PROJECTS ABOUT 4 FEET ABOVE THE SURROUNDING AREA AND IS THE LARGEST BOULDER IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY.  IT IS ABOUT 15 FEET EAST OF THE TREE LINE.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS SET FOR THIS STATION.
markers.setting: SET IN A BOULDER

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA 1924 NORTH OF THE RIGHT-OF-WAY OF THE CANADIAN NATIONAL RAILWAY AT MILEAGE 5.3 FROM SOUTH JUNCTION, IN LINE WITH THE TANGENT OF THE SOUTH RAIL, 2,537 METERS (8,323 FEET) WEST OF THE BEGINNING OF THE FIRST CURVE WEST OF SOUTH JUNCTION, AND 877 METERS (2,877 FEET) WEST OF THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF SEC. 14, T. 1, R. 12 E. SURFACE AND UNDERGROUND MARKS ARE GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA BRONZE DISKS SET IN CONCRETE MONUMENTS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 (WNM) STATION IS ABOUT 5.3 MILES W OF SOUTH JUNCTION AND 877 METERS (2877 FEET) W OF THE NE CORNER OF SECTION 14, T. 1, R. 12 E. IT IS NEAR THE CENTER OF A CLEAR AREA IN THE WOODS ON THE N SIDE OF THE CANADIAN NATIONAL RAILROAD, ON A PROLONGATION OF THE TANGENT OF THE S RAIL, 2537 METERS (8323 FEET) W OF THE BEGINNING OF THE FIRST CURVE W OF SOUTH JUNCTION, 16 FEET S OF THE CENTER LINE OF AN E-AND-W TRACK ROAD AND 3 FEET SSE OF A WHITE REFERENCE POST.  THE SUBSURFACE MARK IS A BRONZE DISK 3 INCHES IN DIAMETER, STAMPED GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA TRIANGULATION STATION, SET IN THE CENTER OF THE TOP OF A RECTANGULAR BLOCK OF CONCRETE 1 FOOT 6 INCHES SQUARE AND 2 FEET HIGH.  THE BASE OF THE BLOCK IS 6 FEET UNDERGROUND.  THE SURFACE MARK IS AN UNSTAMPED BRONZE DISK SET IN THE CENTER OF THE TOP OF A BLOCK OF CONCRETE 1 FOOT 6 INCHES SQUARE AT THE BASE, 1 FOOT SQUARE AT THE TOP, AND 5 FEET 6 INCHES HIGH.  THE TOP PROJECTS 1 FOOT 3 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND AND IS CENTERED VERTICALLY OVER THE SUBSURFACE MARK.  THE AZIMUTH MARK IS ABOUT 0.3 MILE SE OF THE STATION, 40 FEET E OF THE CENTER LINE OF A N-AND-S TRACK ROAD AND 3 FEET W OF A WHITE REFERENCE POST.  IT IS A NAIL SET IN THE CENTER OF A 12-INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE CANADIAN CUSTOMS STATION IN SOUTH JUNCTION, GO W ON THE GRAVEL ROAD ALONG THE S SIDE OF THE RAILROAD FOR 1.9 MILES AND TURN RIGHT, N, ACROSS THE RAILROAD. GO 0.2 MILE AND TURN LEFT, W.  GO 1.0 MILE AND KEEP STRAIGHT AHEAD AT T-ROAD RIGHT.  GO 1.7 MILES AND KEEP STRAIGHT AHEAD, W, WHERE THE MAIN ROAD TURNS LEFT AT WAMPUM.  GO 0.7 MILE AND PASS THROUGH WIRE GATE.  GO 0.3 MILE AND TAKE LEFT FORK, SW.  GO 1.3 MILES AND PASS BETWEEN FARMHOUSE AND BARN.  GO 0.1 MILE AND TAKE RIGHT FORK AT A SMALL BLAZED TREE ON THE RIGHT.  GO W ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.3 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE S SIDE OF THE ROAD.  THIS STATION WAS ESTABLISHED BY THE GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA IN 1924.  THE AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED BY THE U.S. COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY IN 1941.  THERE ARE NO REFERENCE MARKS.  A 103-FOOT SIGNAL AT FOX IS VISIBLE AT 50 FEET.  A 90-FOOT SIGNAL AT DUXBY IS VISIBLE AT 50 FEET.  A 64-FOOT SIGNAL AT PINEY (G.S. OF C.) IS VISIBLE AT 50 FEET.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK - 30 METERS.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1989 THE STATION IS LOCATED NEAR BOUNDARY MONUMENT 925 AT THE NORTH END OF THE MERIDIAN LINE ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE NORTHWEST ANGLE. THE STATION WAS REACHED BY SNOW MACHINE FROM THE NORTHWEST ANGLE RESORT ON CROW CREEK NEAR THE WEST END OF CARLSON AIRFIELD.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTHWEST ANGLE RESORT, GO NORTHEAST DOWN CROW CREEK FOR 0.5 KM (0.30 MI) TO THE NORTHWEST ANGLE INLET.  TURN LEFT AND GO WEST-NORTHWEST FOR 2.6KM (1.60 MI) TO POPLAR CREEK ON THE LEFT. CONTINUE WEST-NORTHWEST FOR 1.8 KM (1.10 MI) TO BEAR CREEK ON THE LEFT.  CONTINUE NORTHWEST FOR 0.8 KM (0.50 MI) TO HARRISON CREEK ON THE LEFT.  BEAR RIGHT, GOING WEST-NORTHWEST ACROSS THE BOG FOR 0.6 KM (0.35 MI) TO THE MERIDIAN LINE AND THE STATION. THE STATION IS A STANDARD 7.0 CM DIAMETER INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION DISK STAMPED --- HARRISON 1980 --- SET INTO THE TOP OF A 47 CM ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 17 CM.  THE STATION IS LOCATED 6.0 M (19.7 FT) EAST OF A BRUSH LINE, 12.7 M (41.7 FT) NORTH-NORTHWEST OF BOUNDARY MONUMENT 925. REFERENCE MARK NO 1 IS A STANDARD 7.0 CM DIAMETER INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION DISK STAMPED --- HARRISON NO 1 1980 --- SET INTO THE TOP OF A 28 CM ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 15 CM, 9.735 M (31.9 FT) EAST-SOUTHEAST OF THE STATION DISK. REFERENCE MARK NO 2 IS A STANDARD 7.0 CM DIAMETER INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION DISK STAMPED --- HARRISON NO 2 1980 --- SET INTO THE TOP OF A 28 CM ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT PROJECTING 20 CM, 10.442 M (34.26 FT) NORTH-NORTHWEST OF THE STATION DISK, 3.0 M (9.8 FT) SOUTHEAST OF A CLUMP OF BRUSH AND 23.1 M (75.8 FT) NORTH-NORTHWEST OF BOUNDARY MONUMENT 925.                            STATION RECOVERY (1995)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1995 (DKH) THE MARK WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED.  RECOVERY NOTE BY DAVID K.  HERDER, TYPED BY G.W.O.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1980 (MDC) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8 1/4 MILES NORTH - NORTHEAST OF WARROAD, 6 3/4 MILES EAST OF WHERE THE INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY INTERSECTS STATE HIGHWAY 313 AND ABOUT 3/4 MILE NORTH - NORTHEAST OF THE EXTREME SOUTHEAST POINT OF BUFFALO POINT.  IT IS ON THE BUFFALO POINT INDIAN RESERVATION.  PERMISSION TO CROSS THE RESERVATION AND ESTABLISH THE STATION WAS GRANTED BY MR JIM THUNDER, CHIEF OF THE RESERVATION, AND HIS BROTHER, FRANK.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE INTERSECTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 11 AND 313 AT THE NORTHWEST EDGE OF WARROAD, GO NORTH ON STATE HIGHWAY 313 FOR 6.5 MILES TO THE CANADIAN CUSTOMS.  CONTINUE FOR 0.1 MILE TO A GRAVEL SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EASTERLY FOR 6.4 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  CONTINUE FOR 0.5 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT AT A LARGE TREE IN THE MIDDLE OF THE ROAD.  CONTINUE EAST THEN NORTH FOR 0.55 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST FOR 0.2 MILE TO A TRAIL THAT LEADS TO THE LAKE AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM HERE, PACK EASTERLY ALONG THE TRAIL TO THE LAKE SHORE THENCE NORTHERLY ALONG THE SHORE TO THE FIRST PROMINENT POINT AND THE STATION.  THIS IS ABOUT A 10 MINUTE PACK.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED JIM 1980.  IT IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A FLAT, LIGHT COLORED BOULDER THAT IS APPROXIMATELY 2 BY 4 FEET AND PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES.  THE STATION WAS ESTABLISHED DURING THE SUMMER OF A VERY DRY YEAR, THEREFORE, DURING A NORMAL YEAR, THE STATION MARK COULD BE UNDER WATER.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED JIM NO 1 1980.  IT IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE POINTED BOULDER NEAR THE EDGE OF THE TREE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A STANDARD DISK STAMPED JIM NO 2 1980.  IT IS CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF A LARGE BOULDER JUST NORTH OF THE STATION.  NO AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.

STATION MARK--A STANDARD GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA STATION MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1947)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1947 (NWS) STATION IS IN SW 1/4 SEC. 7, T. 1, R. 5 W., PRINCIPAL MERIDIAN. THE STATION IS ON A KNOLL ABOUT 400 METERS N OF THE ROAD PARALLEL TO AND ONE MILE N OF THE INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY, AND ABOUT 180 METERS NW OF A HOUSE LOCATED SOME DISTANCE N OF THIS ROAD.  IT IS A LITTLE OVER A MILE E OF THE ROAD FROM THE BOUNDARY N TO MORDEN, MANITOBA.  IN 1947, THE KNOLL WAS COVERED BY, AND IN THE CENTER OF A LARGE WHEAT FIELD, MAKING A SEARCH IMPOSSIBLE.  THE STATION MARK IS A STANDARD G.S. OF C. STATION MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1967)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (JWC) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED.  HOWEVER THE TOP OF THE MARK HAD BEEN BROKEN OFF.  THE UNDERGROUND MARK WAS FOUND INTACT.  THE SURFACE MARK WAS RESET, HOLDING THE EXACT POSITION AS THE UNDERGROUND MARK.  FOLLOWING IS A NEW COMPLETE DESCRIPTION.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 11-1/4 MILES NORTHWEST OF WALHALLA, NORTH DAKOTA, 7 MILES WEST OF HASKETT, CANADA AND 1-1/4 MILES NORTH OF THE CANADIAN BORDER, ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A SMALL KNOLL IN A CULTIVATED FIELD.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN WALHALLA, GO NORTH ON 10TH STREET FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE JUNCTION WITH STATE HIGHWAY 32.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHEAST AND NORTH ON HIGHWAY 32 FOR 5.4 MILES TO THE U.S. CUSTOMS BUILDING ON THE LEFT.  CONTINUE NORTHERLY ON THE HIGHWAY FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE CANADIAN CUSTOMS BUILDING ON THE RIGHT.  CONTINUE NORTH AND WEST ON STATE HIGHWAY 32 FOR 1.6 MILES TO WHERE THE HIGHWAY TURNS RIGHT AND A GRAVELED ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO WEST ON GRAVELED ROAD FOR 5.5 MILES TO A CROSSROAD AND A SIGN MANITOBA 243. CONTINUE WEST ON GRAVELED ROAD FOR 3.1 MILES TO A CROSSROAD. CONTINUE WEST FOR 0.25 MILE TO A DRIVEWAY ON THE LEFT. CONTINUE WEST FOR 0.25 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH FOR 0.3 MILE TO A FARM YARD.  TURN LEFT AND GO WEST, BETWEEN A GRAIN BIN AND TIN BUILDING FOR 0.05 MILE.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON TRACK ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE SOUTH EDGE OF A CULTIVATED FIELD.  FROM THIS POINT GO NORTH AND NORTHWEST ACROSS FIELD FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE KNOLL AND THE STATION.  STATION MARK IS A BRONZE DISK OF THE GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA, STAMPED NUMENDAHL 1925 1967, SET IN THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE POST, 24 INCHES IN DIAMETER, THAT IS 14 INCHES BELOW THE GROUND SURFACE.  THE UNDERGROUND MARK IS 60 INCHES BELOW THE GROUND SURFACE.  REFERENCE MARKS WERE NOT SET AT THE REQUEST OF THE PROPERTY OWNER.  NO SUITABLE LOCATION FOR AN AZIMUTH MARK.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--7 MILES WEST OF HASKETT, CANADA.

STATION RECOVERY (1947)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1947 (NWS) STATION IS ON THE SOUTHERN END OF A HIGH, PARTIALLY TIMBERED RIDGE ABOUT 2 MILES E OF MENISINO, 5 MILES W OF PINEY, OVERLOOKING LOWLANDS TO THE E, S, AND W.  IT IS ABOUT 1/4 MILE N OF THE CANADIAN NATIONAL RAILWAY, 35 FEET N OF THE OLD RIDGE TRAIL AND 4 FEET E OF A WHITE REFERENCE POST.  THE SUBSURFACE MARK IS A BRONZE DISK 3 INCHES IN DIAMETER, STAMPED GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA TRIANGULATION STATION, SET IN THE CENTER OF THE TOP OF A RECTANGULAR BLOCK OF CONCRETE 1 FOOT 6 INCHES SQUARE AND 2 FEET HIGH.  THE BASE OF THE BLOCK IS 6 FEET UNDERGROUND.  THE SURFACE MARK IS A BOLT ENGRAVED WITH A TRIANGLE SET IN THE CENTER OF THE TOP OF A BLOCK OF CONCRETE 1 FOOT 6 INCHES SQUARE AT THE BASE, 1 FOOT SQUARE AT THE TOP, AND 5 FEET 6 INCHES HIGH.  THE TOP PROJECTS 1 FOOT 6 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND AND IS CENTERED VERTICALLY OVER THE SUBSURFACE MARK.  AZIMUTH MARK IS 2 FEET N OF A WHITE REFERENCE POST AND 0.05 MILE N OF A RIDGE TRAIL.  IT IS A NAIL SET IN A 12- BY 12-INCH CONCRETE BLOCK AND PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM PINEY, GO N ON GRAVEL FOR 1.0 MILE, TURN W (RIGHT) AND GO FOR 5.0 MILES ON A GRAVEL ROAD THAT EVENTUALLY CHANGES TO A DIRT TRAIL, TO A CLEARING ON THE S SIDE OF THE ROAD.  TURN LEFT ON DIRT TRAIL AT W EDGE OF CLEARING AND GO 0.75 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.  TO REACH THE AZIMUTH MARK FROM THE STATION, GO E ON THE RIDGE TRAIL FOR 0.25 MILE.  LEAVE TRAIL AND GO 0.05 MILE N (LEFT) TO MARK ON TOP OF A SANDY KNOLL.  AZIMUTH MARK WAS SET BY U.S.C. AND G.S. IN 1941.  A 90-FOOT SIGNAL AT GUILBAULT IS VISIBLE AT 50 FEET.  A 103-FOOT SIGNAL AT FOX IS VISIBLE AT 50 FEET.  A 90-FOOT SIGNAL AT DUXBY IS VISIBLE AT 50 FEET.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK - 22 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1947)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1947 (NWS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1988)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1988 THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8.05 KM (5.00 MI) WEST OF PINEY, MANITOBA, 3.2 KM (2.00 MI) EAST OF MENISINO, MANITOBA AND ABOUT 8.85 KM (5.50 MI) NORTH OF THE U.S. - CANADIAN BOUNDARY. TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE CANADIAN CUSTOMS AT THE PINE CREEK, MINNESOTA - PINEY, MANITOBA BORDER CROSSING, GO NORTH ON MANITOBA PROVINCIAL HIGHWAY 89 FOR 8.36 KM (5.20 MI) TO THE SMALL TOWN OF PINEY.  CONTINUE NORTH FOR 1.61 KM (1.00 MI) TO THE JUNCTION OF PROVINCIAL HIGHWAY 201 ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO WEST ON PROVINCIAL HIGHWAY 201 FOR 8.85 KM (5.50 MI) TO A GRAVEL CROSSROAD. TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON THE GRAVEL ROAD, WHICH BECOMES MORE OF A TRACK ROAD, FOR 1.37 KM (0.85 MI) TO A FORK.  KEEP THE RIGHT FORK AND CONTINUE FOR 0.08 KM (0.05 MI) TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT. THE STATION MARK IS A PUNCH MARK ON A SURVEY DISK STEM WHICH IS SET IN A 0.61 M (2.0 FT) SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT PROJECTS 0.40 M (1.3 FT) ABOVE THE SURFACE, 10.67 M (35.0 FT) NORTH-NORTHWEST OF THE CENTER OF THE TRACK ROAD AND 0.31 M (1.0 FT) SOUTH-SOUTHWEST OF A WITNESS POST. TYPED BY E.A.R.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA 1925 (JGH) ABOUT 4 MILES WEST AND 1 MILE NORTH OF THE TOWN OF SNOWFLAKE, ON THE SUMMIT OF STAR MOUND--THE MOST PROMINENT HILL IN THE LOCALITY, IN SE 1/4 SEC. 27, T. 1, R. 10 W., PRINCIPAL MERIDIAN, AND NEAR THE SOUTH LINE OF THE SECTION.  THE SUMMIT OF THE MOUND IS AN ANCIENT BURIAL GROUND.  IN 1925 THE GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA RECOVERED STATION STAR MOUND IBC AND ESTABLISHED A FIRST-ORDER STATION UNDER THE SAME NAME 39.9 METERS FROM THE ORIGINAL STATION N 76 DEG 57 MIN E. THE NEW STATION IS MARKED BY A STANDARD GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA STATION MARK.  THE REFERENCE MARK IS THE DOMINION LANDS SURVEY POST AT THE CENTER OF THE NORTH LINE OF SEC. 22, T. 1, R. 10 W., 306.58 METERS FROM THE STATION S 79 DEG 36 MIN W.                            STATION RECOVERY (1925)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA 1925 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1988)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1988 THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 9.25 KM (5.75 MI) NORTH-NORTHWEST OF HANNAH, NORTH DAKOTA, 4.83 KM (3.00 MI) WEST-NORTHWEST OF SNOWFLAKE, MANITOBA, AND ABOUT 6.84 KM (4.25 MI) NORTH-NORTHWEST OF THE HANNAH - SNOWFLAKE BORDER CROSSING. TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE CANADIAN CUSTOMS AT THE HANNAH - SNOWFLAKE BORDER CROSSING, GO NORTH ON MANITOBA PROVINCIAL ROAD 242 FOR 6.03 KM (3.75 MI) TO THE JUNCTION OF MANITOBA PROVINCIAL ROAD 201.  TURN LEFT AND GO WEST ON PROVINCIAL HIGHWAY 201  FOR 3.30 KM (2.05 MI) TO A GRAVEL CROSSROAD.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ON A GRAVEL ROAD FOR 1.69 KM (1.05 MI) TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO WEST ON THE GRAVEL ROAD FOR 0.56 KM (0.35 MI) TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT. THE STATION MARK IS SET IN THE TOP OF A 12 INCH SQUARE CONCRETE POST THAT PROJECTS 25.5 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE. TYPED BY E.A.R.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (CMD) ON WEST SIDE OF LAKE OF THE WOODS, ABOUT 1,300 METERS (4.265 FEET) NORTHWEST OF BUFFALO POINT, ABOUT 1,100 METERS (3.609 FEET) NORTH OF INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY AND ON SANDY TIMBERED RIDGE ABOUT 10 METERS (33 FEET) ABOVE LAKE LEVEL.  TO REACH FROM WARROAD, GO BY BOAT TO BUFFALO POINT, FOLLOW TRAIL NORTHWEST ABOUT ONE-FOURTH MILE FROM POINT KEEPING TO LEFT OF SMALL CORNFIELD, TAKE LEFT FORK AND FOLLOW TO SECOND FORK, TAKE RIGHT FORK AND GO ABOUT 275 YARDS TO STATION SITE.  MARKED BY STANDARD BRONZE DISK OF INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION IN CONCRETE BLOCK 14 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  IN 1934 TWO REFERENCE MARKS WERE ESTABLISHED (PROBABLY STANDARD REFERENCE DISKS IN CONCRETE).  NO. 1 IS 87.48 FEET FROM STATION NO. 2 IS 76.28 FEET FROM STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (LMC) STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION TO REFERENCE MARK 1 CHECKED WITH 1934 RECOVERY NOTE.  THE DISTANCE TO REFERENCE MARK 2 WAS FOUND SLIGHTLY SHORTER AND THE DIRECTION DID NOT CHECK. DUE TO VARIOUS CHANGES A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 8-1/4 MILES NORTHEAST OF WARROAD, ON THE WEST SIDE OF LAKE OF THE WOODS, 3/4 MILE NORTH OF U.S.- CANADA BOUNDARY AND ABOUT 4/5 MILE NORTHWEST OF BUFFALO POINT.  TO REACH FROM BOAT LANDING ON SOUTH SIDE OF BUFFALO POINT AND WEST OF AN OLD CABIN, GO NORTHEAST ON TRACK ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A OLD CABIN ON RIGHT, CONTINUE STRAIGHT AHEAD FOLLOWING TRACK ROAD IN A NORTHERLY DIRECTION FOR 0.7 MILE TO A FORK, KEEP RIGHT AND CONTINUE NORTHERLY FOR 0.15 MILE TO DIM TRACK ROAD RIGHT, JUST BEFORE REACHING 3 OLD CABINS ON LEFT, TURN RIGHT AND FOLLOW DIM TRACK ROAD EASTERLY AND SOUTHEASTERLY FOR 0.25 MILE TO REFERENCE MARK 1 ON LEFT AND STATION ON RIGHT AS DESCRIBED.  STATION MARK, A 2 INCH BRONZE DISK WITH LETTERS US AND CB SURVEY AND A SMALL TRIANGLE CAST IN THE DISK, IS SET IN A 18 INCH IN DIAMETER OVAL SHAPED CONCRETE POST WHICH IS SET 6 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  THE MARK IS 78 FEET SOUTHWEST OF CENTER OF TRACK ROAD, 17.5 FEET WEST OF TRIANGLE BLAZED TREE AND 4.3 FEET EAST OF WITNESS POST.  REFERENCE MARK 1, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED THUNDER NO 1 1934, IS SET IN A CONCRETE CYLINDER WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES. THE MARK IS 18 FEET NORTH OF TRIANGLE BLAZED TREE, 9 FEET NORTHEAST OF CENTER OF TRACK ROAD AND 2 FEET SOUTHWEST OF WITNESS POST.  REFERENCE MARK 2, A STANDARD DISK STAMPED THUNDER NO 2 1934, IS SET IN A CONCRETE CYLINDER WHICH PROJECTS ABOUT 6 INCHES.  THE MARK IS 154 FEET SOUTHWEST OF CENTER OF TRACK ROAD, 5.5 FEET NORTHWEST OF TRIANGLE BLAZED TREE AND 1 FOOT SOUTHEAST OF WITNESS POST.  NO SUITABLE PLACE WAS FOUND FOR AZIMUTH MARK.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 26 METERS.
